Only a kaishakunin may so act for a Daimyo.
A Military rank. A commander of Samurai. Cho-han can command up to 50 Samurai and up to 1000 Bushi
Concept of warfare defining the soldiers of a lord as the shield of the castle
Kan, The Shield. The Shield, the Soldier. The Soldier, the Castle.
Spirit called. (literally Spirit House) When a young man or woman believes they have been called to another Tomo than the one they have been born into.
A Small copper coin
- Largest ships in general use. Powered by up to 80 oarsmen. The Adake-bune are used in both trade and war, generally acting as flagships in the latter endeavor.
-Ornamental bow common in armor throughout samurai history.
-The '47 Ronin'
-"Rowdy Monks", an old term for the warrior monks later known as SOHEI.
-Outlaw bands once prevalent in the Kamakura period.

-Also, Amaterasu-o-mi-kami. Shinto deity; the goddess of the sun and progenitor of the Imperial family. The daughter of IZANAGI and IZANAMI, Amaterasu is also said to have taught her people how to cultivate food and raise silk worms. The most important Shinto divinity.
-‘Light feet’: infantry.
-Particularly popular No drama depicting a poignant event in the Succession War, the death of young Taira Atsumori at the Battle of Ichi-no-Tani.
kagami -An important historical work completed in the early
-A term for cavalry.
-‘Tent/Camp government’ Name applied to the headquarters of the shogun in teh field.
-Gourd-shaped lute-a musical instrument that predated the SAMISEN.
-Wooden staff primarily used by non-samurai in the Edo period.
-A defensive battle; to fight on the defensive.
-Wooden sword often used in a swordsman’s training.
-fighting on the defensive, a defensive battle
-Ancient term applied to the martial side of the Japanese culture.
-Term occasionally used in the Edo Period to describe the study of the martial arts; in modern usage, a reference to the martial arts.
-Ancient term used to describe martial combat. The terms Bujutsu and BUDO are derived from Bugei.
-Weapon rack.

-Military house; family whose duties include the bearing of arms -most often applied to those warrior clans prior to and during the Gempei War (1180-85) but in use into and beyond the Momoyama Period. Buke is occasionally- and misleadingly- translated as ‘equestrians’.
-Term referring to the old samurai debate over the relative important of letters and learning versus martial skill.
-Noble; a member of the imperial court.
-Provinces that in the Heian Period are governed by court nobles; in the Sengoku Period, Bunkoku was sometimes used to refer to the territory of a daimyo.
-See ETA.
-Warrior.
-‘Way of the Warrior’. Bushido has come to act as a blanket expression for the philosophy and mindset of the samurai, in particular the ideals of honor and bravery.
-Tea.
-Tea ceremony; a custom refined in the later 15th Century and popular among the samurai and court nobles. Considered in many ways an art form.
-The Way of Tea; a term used to describe the art and practice of the tea ceremony.
-Style of top knot named after it’s resemblance to a tea wisk.
-Unit of land measure that was equivalent to 2.94 acres until 1594, when it was reduced, now equaling 2.45 acres.
-A lord’s personal territory-his personal property.
-A class term for merchants and artisans, who figured in below the peasants and above outcasts on the social scale.
-‘Great Minister of State’-the highest appointment awarded by the imperial court. Rank held by such figures as Taira Kiyomori, Oda Nobunaga, and Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
-Deputy, intendant, manager. Daikan could refer to the official tax collector for a daimyo.
- Carpenter.

-‘Great Name’; term used to describe the autonomous lords of the late 15th and 16th Centuries who exercised personal authority on a multi-province, multi-district, or, in some cases, multi-village level. A term occasionally, and incorrectly, applied to the earlier SHUGO, or misleadingly equated to the shugo. At the same time, the term shugo-daimyo is sometimes used to describe the increasingly autonomous shugo of the early to mid-14the Century, and the term shugo can be found still in use as late as 1560. In the Edo period, the term daimyo generally applied to those lords who governed lands worth more than 10,000 KOKU.
-The Imperial Palace.
-A district magistrate.
-Sword pair formed by the KATANA and WAKIZASHI and worn by the samurai.
-Honorific title for an abdicated emperor.
-‘Country music’, ‘rustic music’; music popular with the common people, often including dance routines as part of a performance.
-Generic term for body armor - that armor which protects the torso; a cuirass.
-Village leader, headman, especially one whose assets allow him a certain amount of political and/or military clout locally.
-Martial arts school or training hall.
-Castle keeps, Donjons are ultimately designed as much for appearance as defensive capability.
-Term for Edo Period ‘police officers’, subordinate to YORIKI.
-Pawnbroker; moneylender
-The copper guild.
-Cap, usually black and often fastened to the head with a silk cord, worn by the samurai in formal circumstances.
-Council, especially one composed of civilian community elders-often applied to the governing merchant body of Sakai.
-Derogative term for the

- Temple complex on Mt. Hiei (Ômi province) founded by the monk Saicho Dengyo-Daishi) in 788. The spiritual capital of the Tendai sect of Buddhism, the Enryakuji maintained a virtual army of warrior monks and played an active (and at times destructive) role in Kyoto politics until 1571. In that year, Oda Nobunaga, whom the Enryakuji had defied, destroyed the Enryakuji and killed thousands of its monks. It was later rebuilt though almost no buildings predate 1571.

-Term used to describe those people who handled tasks considered exceptionally distasteful: executioners, butchers, undertakers, midwives, and tomb attendants - in general, any job which required the handling of the dead or the remains of the dead. Even the makers of leather armor could be considered Eta. The term is possibly derived from Etori, or butcher. Eta are considered practically subhuman, especially in the Edo Period, and to have Eta roots remained a stigma into the 20th Century - currently known as Buraku-min.
-A hereditary vassal-a retainer of long standing.
-‘Benkei aboard ship’, popular No play recounting a legend from 1185 involving Minamoto Yoshitsune, the warrior monk Benkei, and the tragic Shizuka Gozen.
-Loincloth.
-A brave battle; to fight bravely.

-A group dance making use of outlandish costumes to tell an often energetic and occasionally bawdy tale; originally a ritual of exorcism, Furyu was quite popular by the 16th Century, especially among commoners.
-Style of music traditionally favored by the Imperial Court.
- River (examples: Anegawa, Saigawa); also: kawa.
-Scholarly monks.
-‘The low overcome the high’; someone of high standing being unseated by an inferior.
- The conflict between 1180 and 1185 that saw the defeat of the Taira (Heike, Heishi) and the rise to power of the Minamoto (Genji) led by Minamoto Yoritomo.
-Attendants to samurai, whose responsibilities included horse care, equipment maintenance, and so on.
-Coming of age ceremony generally celebrated on a boy’s 14th or 15th birthday. Also known as genbuku.

- The act of a monk returning to lay life. Most sengoku daimyo had rules regulating the return of monks to secular life, presumably because many defeated samurai are spared execution if they took up a monk's habit.
-Estate/SHOEN manager, administrator of the Heian Period.
-Silver guild in the Edo Period.
-A term implying a debt of gratitude, obligation, or a sense of honor; duty.
-Ancient board game with an emphasis on careful strategy, popular throughout Japanese history.
-Work on the principles of sword fighting composed by the swordsman Miyamoto Musashi in the early to mid-16th Century.
-Village; self-governing village important in the later 16th Century and Edo Period.
-Performers or artisans kept on a retainer by a daimyo and allowed special privileges.
-"Stupid commoners"; Edo Period samurai phrase for peasants and townspeople.
-‘War tale’; type of written work that dealt primarily with warriors and their deeds.
-Folding war fan often made out of metal.
-A military service levy or tax.
-Taxpayers in the 16th century who rendered military service or provided soldiers in return for an exemption on rice/money taxation.
-A rivalry of powerful warlords.
- Ministry/Minister of Justice; court rank/office estalished as part of the Taiho Code

- Battle formation; 'fish scale'. Supposedly tilized by some daimyô in the 16th Century, the gyorin was intended to make an army appear as if it are preparing to retreat-thereby tricking an enemy into attacking.
- Traditional white head cloth worn with armor and acting as a helmet pad or cushion.
-Early 18th Century text complied by Tashiro Tsuramoto from the recollections and precepts of Yamamoto Tsunetomo. Considered one of the foremost works of samurai thought.
-Defeat.
-Thigh guard additions to suits of armor that became popular in the 16th Century.
-Large, skirt-like pants worn over a kimono, typically worn by samurai-especially in the Edo Period. A shorter version, a han- bakama, could be found among lower-class samurai and outside classes.
-A Daimyo’s domain in the Edo Period, a relatively modern term.
-Rebellion.
-A tax or obligation that called for one half of the income of a particular holding to be rendered to the Daimyo.
- Plain (example: Mikata ga Hara).
- Traditional armor type normally reserved for the lower classes that protected only the front of the torso. \
-‘Belly-slitting’; a term for SEPPUKU, considered somewhat vulgar and rarely used by samurai.
-Style of armor developed during the 14th Century that was more form fitting than previous armor types and was opened in the back.
-‘Bannerman"; retainers close to the Daimyo/Shogun and accorded certain privileges and special status.
-‘The Tale of the Heike’; a ‘war tale’ relating the fall of the Heike clan composed around 1220.
-A retainer/attendant of lowly rank; a personal retainer of the Ashikaga shogun who filled an ostensibly low-ranking post.
-‘Castle on the plain’, ‘Plain castle’, a castle built on flat ground (as opposed to a YAMASHIRO).
-'Flatland Mountain Castle', a castle built on a rise surrounded by plains.
-Military service, especially after 1590.
-The Northern court.
-The headquarters of a daimyo or general on a campaign.
-A samurai responsible for the guard of a field headquarters; commander of a headquarters’ staff.
-A primary castle mutually supported by satellite castles (Shijo).
-Conch-shell used as a signaling device on the battlefield and for ceremonial purposes.
-Water-filled moat.
-Large, cape-like armor accessory worn mainly in the Heian Period whose exact purpose is unknown.
-Battle formation; 'arrowhead'. A 16th Century formation, the 'hoshi' was intended for a charge-probably a standard formation.
-Farmer, villager, cultivator.
-Market, marketplace.
-A household; family.
-A league or alliance. Also, a generic term for a rebellious or riotous peasant group, from the 15th Century into the Edo Period.
-Type of singing style popular in the late Heian Period.
-A retired emperor.
-Certificates awarded by a Zen master to a student that signified the holder had achieved some degree of enlightenment in Zen.

-Modern term describing a system whereby retired/abdicated emperors continued to rule from behind the scenes. Once commonly translated as ‘government by cloistered emperors’, the term ‘cloistered’ is now considered misleading.
-Archery sport in which live dogs are chased and shot from horseback.
-Stone castle walls.
- Stone mason.
-Affix indicating a temple (i.e. Enryakuji: Enryaku Temple).
- Ministry/Minister of Civil Affairs; court rank/office estalished as part of the Taiho Code (702) and later a ceremonial title.
-Temple complexes that included religious, militant, and economic dimensions; especially those associated with the Jodo Shinshu sect.
-Surcoat, or sleeveless jacket, worn over armor, often by important samurai, especially in the 16th Century.
-Simple iron helmet used by foot soldiers in the 16th Century that doubled as a shallow pot for cooking rations in the field.
-A lower-level official charged with the collection of taxes and the enforcement of laws on an estate level. The jito, created by the Kamakura Bakufu, answered to the SHUGO.
-‘Samurai of the land’, ‘samurai of the soil’-rural samurai who often lived close to the land and are not entirely removed from the peasantry.
- Affix indicating a castle (i.e. Osaka-Jo, Chihaya-jo).
-Room with a raised floor-used by important figures.
-Castle town, especially one of the late16th-17th Century and beyond.
-Prostitute, especially those catering to the lower classes.
-A castellan; a castle keeper-a prestigious posting for the retainer of a Daimyo in the 16th Century.
-The act of following one’s late lord in death through suicide. Generally applied to peacetime incidents of such suicides, junshi was expressly outlawed in the Edo Period.
-"Turnip head’-bulbous arrow head that produced a distinctive noise in flight.

-Popular form of theater developed in the early Edo Period. The Bakufu attempted on six occasions to ban Kabuki (which was considered vulgar) without success. Kabuki did evolve over time, however - featured female players

-The traditional helmet of the samurai, often decorated with a sometimes-elaborate crest. The most common sort of kabuto by the 16th Century was the so-called hachi-mai-bari, or ‘eight applied plates’. This cheap, conservative design was a descendant of the often- ornate kabuto worn by earlier Heian and Kamakura samurai that are designed for using a bow and protecting against arrows.
-"Shadow warrior’; an individual who acted as the double for a daimyo when his appearance on the battlefield or elsewhere needed to be feigned.
-Ancient form of dance-drama that predates NO.
-Daimyo house law, the set of guidelines and/or rules by which the daimyo and his retainers operated.
-A ‘second’; an assistant to the act of suicide, whose job it was to behead the samurai committing suicide after he had cut his belly, so as to minimize the suffering he would have to endure.

-Battle formation; 'crane's wing'. Used by certain daimyô in the 16th Century (notably Takeda Shingen at Kawanakajima in 1561), the kakuyoku was supposedly intended to envelop a retreating or surprised enemy.
-‘Divine Wind’, term given to a typhoon that destroyed the Rhelanian Invasion fleet in 1281
-Formal samurai attire consisting of a KIMONO, HAKAMA, and KATAGINU
-See Mon.
-Unit of cash-equivalent to 1000 MON.

-Phonetic syllabary popular in and after the Heian Period, though generally reserved for the common people and women. Edicts and codes commoners are expected to understand are often written in kanna, as are popular books and the like.
-The value of a holding expressed in a cash sum.
-A letter of commendation, often issued by a daimyo to a valued retainer, especially one who had preformed some meritorious deed or service.
-Imperial Regent;
-The act of committing suicide in remonstration to a lord or in protest; commiting suicide to get a point across.
-Clan elders; those trusted retainers of a daimyo whose service is long and loyal.
-Retainer.
-A daimyo’s retainer band.
-Stiff-shouldered sleeveless jacket worn by samurai over a kimono along with HAKAMA in formal circumstances, especially in the Edo Period.

-Traditional long sword of the samurai constructed through the folding and refolding of a bar of hot metal thousands of times. Reknowned for its toughness and cutting ability, the katana-or tachi-replaced the bow as the primary weapon of the samurai during the later Kamakura period, although it was often secondary to a short spear (YARI) in battle.
-Swordsmith.
- River (also, gawa).
-Type of close lacing used to construct armor.
-Boots made with fur (often from bears) popular among ranking samurai in the Heian Period but rare by the 16th Century.

- 'Courtesan district'; literally meaning 'district of destroyers of cities'; otherwise known as 'pleasure districts', these areas are grudgingly allowed by the Tokugawa bakufu during the Edo Period and catered to all classes.
-A unit of distance equal to 1.818 meters or 6 SHAKU.

-Cadastral study, land surveys conducted by many daimyo in the 16th Century to maximize the lands registered for taxation. Toyotomi Hideyoshi organized the greatest of the land surveys between 1587-1597. Land surveys are patently unpopular with the peasantry and local samurai, sometimes prompting riots and resistance.
-The study and practice of swordsmanship.
-'Blood seal', the act of cutting the fourth finger on one's left hand with a knife and smearing the resultant blood on an oath, below the signer's signature or monogram
-Female Attendant Retainer.
-A monk's ritual shawl or cloak, sometimes worn over armor by samurai who are also Buddhist monks.

-Standard every-day wear throughout Japanese history, designed in part to keep its wearer cool during the summertime. Kimonos are made from cotton, hemp, or silk, depending on the station of the wearer, and changed styles frequently over the centuries. Formal kimono-as a court noble or important samurai might wear-was made of fine silk and was bilious, with especially long sleeves and reaching to the floor. Peasants and foot soldiers often wore half-kimonos-which allowed easy movement and-perhaps more importantly-are cheap.
-Scholarly term describing the"Early Modern' period in Japanese history; the time between the Momoyama and Meiji Periods.
-The right of a samurai to slay disrespectful members of the lower classes in the Edo Period.
-Long handled wooden pipe popular among samurai in the late 16th Century after the introduction of tobacco to Japan.
-Filial piety, especially to one's lord.
-Small, open roof ship found in medieval navies, manned by 20 oarsmen.
- Samurai school established by the Mito Tokugawa house that became well-known and controversial.
-Attack, offensive strike.
-A succesor.
-A daimyo’s realm, his direct sphere of influence-the land a daimyo ruled.

-A unit of rice (44.8 gallons/180 liters) that was used to measure an individual’s wealth and a place’s theoretical productivity. In the 16th Century, a simple samurai might be awarded a stipend of 100 koku a year, while in the Edo Period an income of 10,000 koku was considered Daimyo status. One koku was held to be enough rice to feed one man for a year.
-The value of a holding expressed in koku of rice.

-"Man of the province","provincial"; term used to describe locally powerful samurai families during the Muromachi Period. As they are often not far removed from the peasantry in terms of priorities and concerns, kokujin are very much like jizamurai-if not the same, for all intents and purposes.
-The baggage/supply train for an army in the field.
-District, a subsection of a KUNI (province).
-13-stringed board zither popular from the early Heian Period onward, especially in the Court.

-History of the Takeda clan in the Sengoku Period possibly complied in part by Kosaka Masanobu sometime before 1578 but more recently attributed to Obata Kagenori; one of the first texts to mention the term BUSHIDO.
-'Head bag'; a netted bag used to carry the heads of defeated enemies.
-Court noble(s).
-Highly placed court nobles.
-Dues levied in corvee labor, a requirement to send men for provincial work.
-Province.
-Term for a castle compound.
-Communities within a city; a large town; a division (block) of a city.
-Edo Period town or city magistrates that handled many civil tasks for their daimyo, especially when he was away serving in Edo. Edo itself counted two machi-bugyo.
-A scroll.
-Sincerity, pureness of intention.
-Camp curtains enclosing a leader’s headquarters while on campaign or on an outdoor excursion. Maku are essentially silk walls and are not ‘roofed’. Also known as jinmaku and tobari.
-The chief governing body of an important family or monastic complex;
-Face mask or plate worn with armor
-Lesser officials who in the Edo Period appear to have handled under-cover police work and acted as spies for the Tokugawa government.
-A depiction of a journey and the emotions that accompany it in a song, poem, or book.
- 'House/houses of the people', a broad term for a variety of residential housing.
- Port town.
- Ministry/Minister of Popular Affairs;
-Family crest, often displayed on flags, formal clothing, and armor - especially after the 15th Century.
-‘The Tale of…’, ‘The Story of…’ when affixed to a title (i.e. Heike Monogatari). Also used to describe Japanese fictional prose between the 9th and 16th Centuries in general.
-Topknot.
-Edo period daimyo who held an income of 10,000-20,000 koku but no castle.
-Village.
-A land holding registered to a cultivator family that taxation and service came to be based upon in the Shoen system.
-The rice fields contained within a given MYO.
-Rights holders to a MYO; a patriarchal family of cultivators that managed a MYO and paid taxes on it to their governor.

-A mid-sized pole-arm topped with a curving blade popular in the Heian Period. Originally the weapon of a foot soldier, the naginata came to be known as the favored weapon of the warrior monks (SOHEI) and women. The naginata was not otherwise in general use by the 16th Century.

-‘Southern Barbarians’, term applied to Westerners, especially in the 16th century-presumably in reference to the fact that most arriving Spanish, Dutch, and Portuguese ships came from ports south of China.
-A term sometimes applied to village elders.
-The planning of a castle’s defensive lay-out-in particular the placement of the outer walls.
-Year Period or reign name - dating practiced borrowed from the Rhelanian
-An annual land tax or rent.
-A policy whereby daimyo would refuse to allow certain commodities to cross their borders; essentially a form of economic warfare.
-Traditional form of theater popular among the court and samurai that makes use of dance, costumes, music, and a chorus to portray an often-complex tale.

-Long, vertical flag popular in Japan after the 15th Century; carried by the retainers of a daimyo in battle (and the daimyo himself) and displaying individual family crests, patterns, or written characters.
-‘Field Sword’; an extremely large two-handed sword

-‘Lord of…’; originally given to the lord of a certain place, by the 16th Century –no Kami was largely honorific, being dispensed frequently by all daimyô and regardless of whoever else might happen to be ‘lord’ of the province ‘awarded’. The term 'no kami' was literally translated 'Spirit of', and also applied to Shinto deities (Amaterasu no kami, for instance).
- Farming village.
'Deputy Lord of...'; another honorific title
- Lacquerers

-A relatively simple suit of armor extremely common in the 16th Century, constructed by riveting together strips of metal. Probably introduced sometime around 1555, the Okegawa-do could be produced cheaply, easily maintained, and was well suited to Sengoku warfare. Like most armor of the period, Okegawa-do was tapered to allow the wearer’s waist to support the armor’s weight.
- National Treasury; court rank/office estalished as part of the Taiho Code
-Inspector general in the Tokugawa Shogunate.
-A reward of land given by a daimyo to a retainer for exceptional service.
-An Ogre, or particularly violent and brutal person.
-Astrologer.
-A castle.
-A castle’s main gate.

-Elaborate suit of armor in general use during the Heian Period and among important figures into the Sengoku Period. Often constructed with many thousands of strips of laminated bamboo, the O-Yoroi was expensive and box-like, intended for use by samurai on horseback. It was impractical for fighting on foot and therefore fell out of favor as the samurai went from bowman to spear- and swordsman. Daimyo continued to wear variants of the traditional O-Yoroi, however, up until the 19th Century.
-Term used, especially among the Go-Hojo, for irregular troops otherwise described as NINJA.
-a confused, wild battle (lit., chaos battle).
-Linked verse poetry, often composed of 31 syllables in two parts.
-A unit of linear measure equal to 2.445 miles.
-An emperor’s personal edict.

-‘Wave Man’; a masterless samurai. Many samurai are made ronin by the vicissitudes of the sengoku Period, and so formed the basis for many bandit groups and outlaw bands that plagued the countryside into the Edo Period. Though not employed by a daimyo, a ronin was still entitled to wear his swords.
-Generic term applied to both civil and military servants.
-Unit of gold currency.
-"Dominal Province"; a Daimyo’s territory.
-Baton carried by leaders to aid in the direction of troops; worn at the waist when not in use.
-Describes the portion of the head shaved by many samurai.
- Rice wine. Sakê was traditionally produced in the winter months by brewers and created through a process of the breakdown of rice grains by a fungus and fermentation.
-Three-stringed lute introduced from China and popular from the late-16th Century on. Best-known as a woman’s instrument.

-"One who serves"; the traditional warrior class of Japan until 1876. While of obscure origins, the samurai emerged as a powerful force by the 10th Century and after 1192 acted as the de facto rulers of Japan. Until the 1590’s, the status of samurai was somewhat fluid, and within the grasp of those born in the lesser classes-especially in times of war. In the 16th century, many samurai worked alongside the peasantry until they are called to service. After Toyotomi Hideyoshi’s clampdown on social mobility, all men who carried arms are considered samurai (or varying ranks) and made to live in the castle town of their daimyo. With no more battles to fight, the Edo samurai refined their ways of thinking and in many ways shaped the romantic way in which samurai history is now perceived.
-The Imperial Regelia, The Three Treasures: The Mirror, Sword, and Bead Strand whose ownership was necessary for a legal imperial succession.
-‘Monkey music’, a term that theater was commonly known by in the early 15th Century. The phrase Sarugaku no no meant, roughly, ‘theater of the best kind’ and provided the better known title of NO.
-Small banner affixed to the back of a suit of armor, for battlefield recognition purposes
- a sudden enlightenment.
-Political marriage.
-Medium-sized ship operated by a 40-man crew.
-Toll barriers. One of the ways sengoku daimyo gathered income. Tollbooths are particularly unpopular.

-Style of 16th century armor otherwise known as Yukinoshita-do made famous by its extensive use in the army of Date Masamune (of Sendai, Mutsu). Also known as kanto-do and oshu-do. This style of armor was notable for its ease of construction and the ability to customize its appearance based on the rank of the owner.
-Sengoku Jidai, ‘The Country at War’. 1477-1600. The term Sengoku jidai is taken from a roughly comparable episode in Chinese history.

-Ritual suicide: the act of killing one's self by slitting open his belly. Possibly first carried out by Minamoto Yorimasa in 1180, seppuku came to be the 'official' manner of suicide for a samurai, and was prohibited for all other classes. In time, seppuku came to take on religious connotations, but in essence the exceedingly painful manner of dying it brought was a mark of grime pride to the samurai-a final test of his bravery. By the 16th Century a 'second' (or KAISHAKU) had been added to the ritual, to limit the amount of suffering the samurai who was to die would experience. When a female member of a samurai house committed seppuku, she almost always did so by slitting her own throat.
-A unit of linear measure equal to 0.995 feet, or 10 SUN.

- Satellite castle or fort that acts as part of a defensive system anchored by a primary castle (Honjô). The average shijo was a simple stockade constructed from wood and making use of earthen walls, and often fully garrisoned only in emergencies.
-'Hall for sleeping'; the central structure in residencial complexes that gave its name to the overall style of such establishments: shiden zukuri.
-Regency
-Under the Shoen system, rights to a particular holding that entitles the owner a fixed percentage of the annual crop.
- Ministry/Minister of Ceremonies
-Neck guard that hands from the bowl of a samurai’s KABUTO.
-‘True Word’: Buddhist sect founded by Kukai in the early 9th Century. Shingon is sometimes described as ‘esoteric Buddhism’ due to the stress it placed on mysticism and ritual.
-Japan’s indigenous religion, based in part on the worship of spirits.
-Actor, especially in NO.
-Term used after 1869 to refer to former samurai.
-Private estate exempted from central government control and often subject to a multi-layered proprietorship.
-Japanese chess.
- The second of Japan's national histories.
- Craftsman, one who worked with their hands.
-The first attack in a battle or war.
-An affix meaning ‘unit’, or ‘formation’-as in teppo-shu (rifle unit) or Kuni-shu (Provincial unit).

-Provincial governors assigned by the Minamoto Shogunate in the 1190s and an important part of Bakufu control until the Onin War (1467-77). Many of the older shugo families are weakened in the Onin fighting, and then over-thrown or destroyed in the Sengoku Period. During the Kamakura Period, the shugo are largely responsible for upholding the will of the Bakufu, defeating rebels, and overseeing the activities of provincial JITO. Shugo could be roughly translated as ‘Protector’, and in the Muromachi Period a given shugo might control a number of far-flung provinces. The term shugo can be found in records as late as the 1560 in certain provinces (such as Satsuma).
- Post town, a village or town that catered to traffic along one of Japan's primary road circuits.
-Universal Bakufu term for ‘elders’.
-Warrior monks; relatively modern term describing the armed warriors that acted as military muscle for major religious establishments
-The act of committing suicide to make up for an offense or failure to one’s lord.
-Backgammon, popular in medieval Japan.
- 'Abode of refinement', a style of architecture that stessed understatement and irregularity.
-Traditional form of wrestling that was once part of religious festivals
-A unit of linear measure equal to 1.193 inches.
-Term for sword, specifically the long sword carried by the samurai; KATANA.
-Short socks, designed with a split toe so as to be worn with sandals.
-Chronicle of the Nambuchuko Period compiled by the monk Kojima and others around 1370-1372.
-'Great Treasure', a sweeping law code.
- Retired Imperial Regent
